qas.question: What word means that bacteria won't grow on a substrate?
Because of copper's biostatic properties where is a common use for copper?
What has pure copper been replaced with in the building of ships?
In the aquaculture industry what is copper alloys commonly used to make?
Name a property that makes copper a good material to use in marine environments?
What word means that bacteria constantly grows on a substrate?
Where is copper commonly used due to not having a biostatic property?
What has fake copper been replaced with in the building of ships?
What is copper alloys rarely used to make in the agriculture industry?

context: Copper is <a0_0><b5_0>biostatic<b5_0/><a0_0/>, meaning bacteria will not grow on it. For this reason it has long been used to line parts of <a1_0><b6_0>ships<b6_0/><a1_0/> to protect against barnacles and mussels. It was originally used pure, but has since been superseded by <a2_0><b7_0>Muntz metal<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Similarly, as discussed in copper alloys in aquaculture, copper alloys have become important <a3_0><b8_0>netting materials<b8_0/><a3_0/> in the aquaculture industry because they are antimicrobial and prevent biofouling, even in extreme conditions and have strong structural and <a4_0>corrosion-resistant<a4_0/> properties in marine environments.
